document_data.name: Hound of Ill Omen
document_data.mainbody: The '''hound of ill omen''' was a legendary, planar canine beast that appeared to punish mortals for major transgressions against a [[deity]] or to defend [[shadow mage]]s that called upon its protection.
document_data.Description: This creature appeared to be a dark, shadowy [[wolf]]-hound that stood {{SI|5|ft|long=yes}} tall at the shoulder.
document_data.Behavior: The hound of ill omen had a basic, animal level of intelligence.

Abilities.Offensive:
Upon appearing, they unleashed a booming howl that all creatures within {{SI|120|ft|long=yes}} of it could hear. Afterwards, the hound of ill omen would walk off.

Those who could both see and hear the hound would suffer from the magical effect of its howl—the next ten injuries they suffered would be more severe. If ''[[remove curse]]'' was cast on the target soon after, this would be decreased to five. Until the requisite number of injuries was met, no manner of healing [[spell]]s would work on the target. In addition, the injuries sustained had to be outside of a creature's control. If the victim of a hound of ill omen was involved in its killing, then their curse would become even more severe and ''remove curse'' could not lessen it.

Creatures subjected to the howl of a hound of ill omen were immediately aware of their transgression against a deity and received an empathic feeling of both death and dread. However, they would be unaware of the nature of their [[curse]] until they first suffered an injury.

document_data.Combat: The hound of ill omen did not attack its targets directly.

Ecology.Diet: The hound of ill omen fed from the power of its deity and required no other form of nourishment.
Ecology.Habitats: These creatures were always found on the home planes of deities.
Ecology.Relationships: The hound of ill omen served a variety of deities, They were never known to be attacked by the minions of other deities when on their travels or on a mission.

document_data.Rumors & Legends: Some rumors claimed that there was only one of these hounds in existence, while some sages believed that they were merely manifestations of a deity's will, rather than a true creature.
